This tractate differs from Derek ’Ereẓ Rabbah in that its teachings are directed mainly at scholars. A close examination reveals that the tractate is not the work of one author. In the editions of the Talmud, chaps. V-VIII are noted as having been taken from the Maḥzor Viṭri. The author of Halakoth Gedoloth quotes the section corresponding to chaps. V-VIII under the name of Derek ’Ereẓ Zuṭa, but designates the other chapters Darkan shel Talmidë Ḥakamim, which is the opening phrase of chap. I.

It is possible that an unknown author compiled this shortened form of Derek ’Ereẓ and called it Zuṭa, and subsequently the term Rabbah may have been added to the original work to distinguish it from the smaller digest. The language and style of Zuṭa presuppose a much later date, probably after the completion of the Talmud. In some instances it is evident that the author must have had the Talmud before him. The first four chapters, however, appear to date from an earlier period. They may even have been an independent collection already in existence in the time of the Tannaïm, as they contain material which is old and often quoted as Baraithoth by the early authorities.

The different sections were put together by a later compiler, because all have the common factor that they contain exhortations to self-examination and meekness, and advocate temperance, resignation, gentleness, patience, respect for age, readiness to forgive, and the moral and social duties of a scholar.

Zuṭa is written mostly in the form of short, pithy and disconnected maxims arranged in the style of Pirḳë Aboth, except that they are anonymous. Here, too, the compiler attempted to arrange the teachings as far as possible according to external characteristics, the order followed being determined by the initial word or by the number of maxims. Precepts beginning with the same word are placed together even when unrelated in subject-matter. Especially are they so combined into groups of four, five or seven maxims, numbers which serve as an aid in memorizing the passages.

It has already been mentioned in the Introduction to Derek ’Ereẓ Rabbah that in Coronel’s edition of Ḥamishshah Ḳunṭrasim we find many passages in Kallah Rabbathi, with Gemara attached, which really belong to Derek ’Ereẓ. They are as follows: III-V in KR are similar to I-III in DEZ, while VI, VII, IX and X in KR are similar to III-XI in DER.
<small>ANALYSIS OF THE TRACTATE</small>

In chaps. I-IV disciples are exhorted to devote themselves to the study of the Torah, to be humble, modest and sin-fearing. The conclusion of chap. IV may well have been an oration delivered at the ordination of a Rabbi.
Chaps. V-VIII contain rules of conduct for various occasions such as when eating and drinking, and on social behaviour in general. Here we find repetitions of and similarities to the contents of DER.
Chap. IX consists of advice given by R. Eliezer Ha-Ḳappar to one of his disciples on a variety of subjects.
Like the Pereḳ Hashshalom, chap. X was probably a separate work which was later attached to the tractate. It deals with the signs of the coming of the Messianic era.

In DEZ the lack of redaction is more marked than in DER. In its present form it is later than DER (probably third century) and was quoted by ’Amoraïm as Baraithoth and interpreted by teachers of the fourth century. The fact that the Geonim make mention of this tractate indicates that its final redaction must have taken place before that of the Babylonian Talmud.
[In the Talmud editions the chapters are not subdivided, but for the sake of convenience the numbering of the paragraphs has been adopted mainly from Higger’s edition.]
M. GINSBERG.

The characteristics of a scholar are that he is meek, humble,1(1) Cf. Aboth IV, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 45). alert, filled [with a desire for learning],2(2) H reads memullaḥ, ‘bright’, as in Ḳid. 29b (Sonc. ed., p. 141). Cf. KR III, 2, p. 443, n. 13. modest, beloved by all, humble to the members of his household and sin-fearing. He judges a man [fairly] according to his deeds,3(3) He does not, e.g., interpret a man’s good actions as determined by ulterior motives and does not show favour where it is not deserved. and says ‘I have no desire for all the things of this world because this world is not for me’. He sits and studies,4(4) H omits ‘and studies’. soiling his cloak at the feet of the scholars.5(5) For meṭannef H reads mith‘aṭṭef, ‘wrapped in his cloak’, perhaps in the same sense as in Aboth I, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 3), ‘Suffer thyself to be covered by the dust of their feet’, i.e. sit in the dust on the ground at their feet while they teach. GRA reads maṭṭil, ‘and throws his cloak in front of the feet of scholars’, perhaps for them to sit on. For a different explanation, cf. KR III, p. 444, n. 17. In him no one sees any evil. He questions according to the subject-matter6(6) Cf. Shab. 3b (Sonc. ed., pp. 5f.), ‘R. Ḥiyya said to Rab: “When Rabbi is occupied with one tractate, do not ask him a question relating to another” ’. and answers to the point.7(7) lit. ‘in accordance with the accepted decision’.

Be like a gourd split open that the wind may enter,8(8) Let your mind be open to receive instruction. For readings which add the negative, cf. ARN p. 85 and KR p. 449. like a deep furrow which retains its water,9(9) Such a bed yields good produce; so must a scholar study continuously and raise good disciples. like a jar coated with pitch which preserves its wine,10(10) i.e. he must have a retentive memory. and like a sponge which absorbs all.11(11) Cf. Aboth V, 18 (Sonc. ed., V, 15, p. 69). Be not like a wide opening which allows the wind to rush in,12(12) i.e. do not cultivate associates indiscriminately, yet do not be so unapproachable that worthy companionships cannot get near to you. Or, do not create a stir on entering and leaving; or, do not allow petty and frivolous ideas to enter your mind. or like a narrow opening which injures the valuable [as they press through].13(13) By having to stoop or squeeze in; i.e. do not cause people worthy or your association to demean themselves or hold aloof. Be like a doorstep on which everyone treads14(14) i.e. be ready to learn from all. and like a low peg which is within the reach of all.15(15) lit. ‘on which all hang [their things]’.

If you suffered monetary loss, remember Job who was smitten both financially and physically. If you have been smitten physically, remember Dathan and Abiram who descended alive into Sheol.16(16) Cf. Num. XVI, 32f.

Do not be enticed into sin by your eyes, because enticement into sin is caused only through the eyes.17(17) Cf. Soṭah 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 35), ‘We have learnt a tradition that the evil impulse only bears sway over what a person’s eyes see’.

Do not cause yourself to feel ashamed by your teeth18(18) GRA reads: ‘Do not be attracted to appetizing dishes’. lest you eat more than is good for you.19(19) lit. ‘more than is sufficient’. NY quotes a reading: ‘That you do not give them too much to eat’. Another and better variant is: ‘That you eat not’, etc., i.e. shello’ instead of shemma’.

Do not turn away from meritorious deeds and do not be attracted to heresy.20(20) Heb. minuth, a term for the teachings of the early Jewish-Christians. Do not inquire of Sadducees21(21) A party holding views antagonistic to those of the Pharisees. They regarded only those observances obligatory which are in the written Torah and did not acknowledge what was derived by Rabbinical interpretation. lest you be drawn into Gehinnom.22(22) By abandoning the Torah.

If others speak evil of you, answer them not; should it be a serious [calumny], regard it as slight. If, however, you spoke evil of others, though [the calumny] be slight, regard it as serious [and do not rest] until you go and pacify them.23(23) On the evil of slander, cf. ‘Arak. 15b (Sonc. ed., pp. 86ff.).

Let not your [behaviour during] adolescence be of blemished repute, for this would be derogatory to the Torah; but let it be of unblemished repute, for this would tend to glorify the Torah.24(24) The translation follows GRA.
Love and honour the Torah.25(25) By carrying out your duties towards God. Love your fellow-creatures and respect them.26(26) By observing your duties towards them.

Set aside your will in face of the will of your fellow,27(27) When they conflict; cf. Aboth II, 4 (Sonc. ed., p. 14). for so did Rachel towards Leah and David towards Saul.28(28) Cf. KR IV, p. 454f. Set aside your will and the will of your fellow in face of the will of Heaven, for so we find it with Jacob who did not kiss Joseph.29(29) Cf. ibid.

Love the [term] ‘perhaps’ and hate the [expression] ‘how much?’30(30) i.e. ‘how much harm will it do to me?’ Or, be envious of others by saying, ‘Look how much So-and-so possesses!’ R. Ḥidḳa expressed this in another way: Love the [term] ‘perhaps’ and hate the [expression] ‘what of it?’31(31) If I commit this trivial sin; so GRA, lit. ‘What is in it?’ it is of little consequence.
Keep aloof from anything that may lead to sin, from anything hideous and from whatever seems hideous,32(32) Cf. Ḥul. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 239). lest others suspect you of sin.
Slander not your fellow because there is no remedy for him who slanders his fellow.
Do not eat bread with a kohen who is an ‘am ha-’areẓ lest he give you sacred food to eat.33(33) Cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 56).
Refrain from grumbling lest you grumble against others and be led into further sin.34(34) Cf. below, IX, 1, p. 589.

There were seven patriarchs with whom a divine covenant was made, viz.: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, Aaron, Phinehas and David. In connection with Abraham it is written, In that day the Lord made a covenant with Abraham saying.35(35) Gen. XV, 18. In connection with Isaac it is written, But My covenant will I establish with Isaac.36(36) ibid. XVII, 21. In connection with Jacob it is written, Then will I remember My covenant with Jacob.37(37) Lev. XXVI, 42. In connection with Moses it is written, For after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel.38(38) Ex. XXXIV, 27. In connection with Aaron it is written, It is an everlasting covenant of salt before the Lord.39(39) Num. XVIII, 19. In connection with Phinehas it is written, And it shall be unto him, and to his seed after him, the covenant of an everlasting priesthood.40(40) ibid. XXV, 13. In connection with David it is written, I have made a covenant with My chosen, I have sworn unto David My servant.41(41) Ps. LXXXIX, 4. Perhaps this passage is quoted here to teach men to emulate their special characteristics. Abraham stands as the example of hospitality, Isaac of self-sacrifice, Jacob of scholarship (cf. Gen. XXV, 27, where according to Rabbinic interpretation tents means schools), Moses of meekness, Aaron of peace-making, Phinehas of zeal on behalf of God, and David of singing His praise.

The following seven patriarchs have gone to their eternal rest with great honour and worms and maggots had no dominion over them, viz.: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, Aaron, Miriam and their father Amram.42(42) In B.B. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 86), ‘and Benjamin the son of Jacob’. Some say: Also David, as it is stated, Therefore my heart is glad, and my glory rejoiceth; my flesh also dwelleth in safety.43(43) Ps. XVI, 9, the last words being understood as ‘unaffected by worms’.

There were nine44(44) For the list, cf. KR III, p. 461, and notes who entered the Garden of Eden alive, viz.: Enoch the son of Yered, Elijah, the Messiah, Eliezer the servant of Abraham, Hiram, king of Tyre,45(45) It is more likely that the word king has crept in by mistake and the text should read ‘Hiram of Tyre’, who was of the tribe of Naphtali (1 Kings VII, 13f.). Ebed-melech the Cushite, Jabeẓ the son of R. Judah the Prince, Bithiah the daughter of Pharaoh, and Seraḥ the daughter of Asher. Some say: Also R. Joshua b. Levi.
Let all your undertakings be for the name of Heaven.2(2) Having a sincere and high purpose. ‘Heaven’ is a term for God. Love Heaven and fear Heaven. Hurry to perform in gladness all the precepts.

Sit before the Elders and incline your ear to hear their words. Listen carefully to the words of your fellow; be not hasty to answer but give proper thought to your words. Speak of the first [point] first and of the last [point] last, and admit the truth. Speak not before him who is greater than you in wisdom.

If you desire to study,3(3) H adds ‘the Torah’. do not say regarding what you do not understand, ‘I understand’.4(4) GRA reads: ‘and if he desires to teach [you a certain subject], do not say, “I have heard it” ’. If you are questioned on [even] a trivial matter and you are not acquainted with it, be not ashamed to say, ‘I do not know’. If you were taught something which you did not grasp, be not ashamed to say [to the teacher], ‘Repeat it to me’ and do not pretend to yourself ‘I understood it’.

Do [good] deeds for the sake of their Maker5(5) i.e. God, Who decreed them (so RN to Ned. 62a); but Baḥya ibn Paḳuda, in the Introduction to his Duties of the Heart, interprets, ‘for the performance of them’, i.e. doing good for its own sake and not from an interested motive. and speak of them6(6) viz. words of Torah. for their own sake.7(7) i.e. do not study in order to be called a Sage or Rabbi; cf. Ned. 62a (Sonc. ed., p. 197). So according to the emended text of GRA. Make not of them a crown wherewith to adorn yourself, an axe with which to chop or a spade with which to dig.8(8) Cf. Aboth IV, 7 (Sonc. ed., IV, 5, p. 46). Undertake to study the Torah [even] in straitened circumstances and disregard any insult. A well-ordered [moral] stock-taking and a virtuous adolescence [yield] security and truth.9(9) GRA’s emendation may mean: ‘and your security will be real’, or, ‘your promise [which you give] will be true’. An alternative rendering of V may be: ‘[If your deeds] are well considered, and you have good breeding, your promise will be trustworthy’. Cf. the reading in KR IV, 7, p. 466.

Love and honour the Torah; love righteous ways, reproofs10(10) Levelled at you. Cf. Reprove a wise man, and he will love thee (Prov. IX, 8). and uprightness. Do not run after honour; do not be presumptuous in giving decisions. Realize that from now until tomorrow everything you have, whether it belongs to you or not, is not yours;11(11) ‘Is not yours’ is added by GRA. because what is yours is [in reality] not yours, so how can what is not yours be yours! Of him who regards what is not his as his own, Scripture declares, Woe to him that increaseth that which is not his! How long? and that ladeth himself with many pledges!12(12) Hab. II, 6.

Accustom yourself to end on an auspicious note.13(13) i.e. if you must criticize or predict misfortune, your last words should inspire confidence and comfort. Or, ‘accustom yourself to finish anything good which you began to do’, otherwise it will be credited to him who completes it. Other possible interpretations are: ‘Accustom yourself to complete a deal with goodness’, i.e. there should be no cause for resentment by the other party; ‘Accustom yourself to end everything well’. Be modest and amiable towards all, and be humble and gentle of speech. Be quick [to render service] to a superior and easy of approach to a suppliant [for your service].14(14) Cf. DER II, p. 540, n. 41. [Be like] a good merchant15(15) Who can distinguish between the genuine and the spurious; so know how to react towards different types of persons. and broad-shouldered.16(16) i.e. able to deal with all types. H reads reḥab kesef, ‘liberal with money’. Another interpretation is: ‘Be like a good merchant (i.e. well stocked with goods so that a customer need not be kept waiting while the required article is brought from outside), and like a carrier who can carry a big load easily’. The meaning may then be: Be well stocked and carry a heavy load of learning, so that you are ready to supply knowledge to an inquirer.

Keep aloof from anything which may bring you to sin. Recoil from [even] a minor sin that it may not lead you to a major sin. Hasten to [perform] a light precept17(17) Cf. Ps. CXIX, 60. One is more liable to be slack and procrastinating with an easy task and so forget it; to obviate this a man should hasten to perform it as soon as it presents itself. and flee18(18) Not merely avoid, but put as long a distance as possible between yourself and transgression. from even] a trivial transgression lest it will lead you to commit a grave transgression.

Let the honour of your fellow be as dear to you as your own.19(19) Cf. Aboth II, 15 (Sonc. ed., II, 10, p. 20). Show respect to all persons; say not, ‘I will flatter this man that he may give me to eat, or that he may give me to drink, or another man that he may clothe me, or yet another that he may give me shelter’.20(20) Cf. Beẓah 32b (Sonc. ed., p. 165): ‘He who is dependent on another’s table, the world is dark for him and his life is no life’. It is better that you be ashamed of yourself21(21) i.e. be the first to recognize your faults and rectify them. than be put to shame by others.22(22) Cf. Sanh. 42a (Sonc. ed., p. 274). Let not your teeth bring shame upon you,23(23) i.e. by spending more than you can afford on food so that you become reduced in circumstances. nor your mouth bring you to abuse.24(24) By drinking more than is good for you. Let not your tongue [cause others to] curse you or your lips discredit you, and do not bow down to your words.25(25) Do not speak in haste without premeditation so that you will not have to humble yourself by asking pardon or having to retract. Other possible interpretations are: Do not regard your words as dogmatic; or, do not be self-opinionated; or, do not be a slave to your words, i.e. refrain from making a promise. H reads tishtaḥ, ‘do not spread your words’, i.e. do not be verbose.

If you desire to secure your fellow’s love, concern yourself with his welfare. If you want to keep away from sin, go, reflect and consider its consequences well. Take delight in the performance of a miẓwah, study hard and exult in [carrying it out] in all its details.26(26) So GRA who conjectures bifraṭeha, but there is no MS. confirmation for it. A suggested reading is, shekan urebaẓ biftaḥeha, ‘Dwell and couch at the doors of [the Academy]’; i.e. by constant study make yourself familiar with the miẓwoth.

If you did [someone] a great favour regard it as small, and do not say, ‘I did this good act with my own [money]’. Rather was it [from what God] had graciously given you and you should offer thanks to Heaven.27(27) For the means with which to do good. If others have done you a slight favour regard it as if it were great, and do not say, ‘The favour was done to me because of my worthy acts’, but [say, ‘In spite of] my unworthy acts a favour was done to me’, as it is stated, And repayeth them that hate Him to their face, to destroy them.28(28) Deut. VII, 10. It is better not to receive the reward in this world but to store it up for the hereafter If you wronged someone slightly regard it as a great wrong and exclaim, ‘Woe is me, for I have sinned! Woe is me, because harm was done through me!’ If others did you a great wrong regard it as small and exclaim, ‘I suffered slightly; I deserved more’.

Reflect before [the word] issues from your mouth. Consider your actions in accordance with good manners. Set a reward for every step you take.1(1) i.e. see that your steps are directed to perform deeds which deserve a reward. Submit to [divine] judgment and refrain from grumbling. Judge your fellow in the scale of merit2(2) Seek a favourable interpretation of his actions even though they seem suspicious. Cf. Aboth I, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 5). and do not turn the scale against him.3(3) Take a charitable view of his deeds. Rejoice in your lot and enjoy the little you have. Hate not him who reproves you. Your lot will always be blessed if you possess a bountiful eye4(4) Well disposed, generous; cf. Prov. XXII, 9. and a contented soul.
Accustom your tongue to say, ‘I do not know’, lest you be led to falsehood and be apprehended.

If you are negligent in [the performance of] one precept you will eventually be negligent with another like it. If you belittle5(5) lit. ‘speak lightly of’. one precept you will eventually belittle others like it.6(6) V adds in brackets ‘and you have done nothing for your trouble’ in fulfilling the precepts since you regard them of small worth. If you transgress the words of the Torah intentionally, you will be made to transgress them intentionally or unintentionally.7(7) Circumstances will make it impossible for you to perform the precepts even if you are desirous of making good former lapses. [58b] If you take for yourself anything which is not yours, what is yours will be taken from you.
Be careful with consecrated objects both when giving them8(8) To the kohen or Levite; do not withhold them. and when eating them.9(9) They must be eaten in a state of ritual cleanliness.

Be humble and affable to all persons and particularly to the members of your household.10(10) According to the text emended by GRA. V and H read: ‘Be humble and affable to return [a salutation] to your acquaintance. Be lowly of spirit with all men, with the members of your household more than with all men; and if you grumble and fight with your household, your end is for Gehinnom’.
The first stage of vowing leads to folly; the first stage of [ritual] uncleanness leads to idolatry; the first stage of levity with women leads to unchastity.11(11) Cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 56).

If you make yourself a surety [for another] it should be with the object of paying [that surety];12(12) If called upon to do so. or if you become a guarantor it should be with the object of paying [the guarantee].13(13) Therefore do not offer to become a guarantor lightheartedly. If you borrow [money] it should be with the object of repaying [the loan];14(14) So borrow only if you are in a position to repay. and if you lend money bear in mind that you may have to claim it15(15) And have difficulty in collecting it. and that you might [even] have to make a settlement.16(16) And lose part of the sum loaned. Another reading is lehafsid, ‘lose the sum’.

If one has acquired for himself a good name,17(17) Cf. Prov. XXII, 1; Eccl. VII, 1; Aboth II, 8 (Sonc. ed., II, 7, p. 17). he has acquired it for himself.18(18) In the sense that, unlike any other possession, it cannot be transmitted to another. If one has acquired for himself words of Torah, he has acquired for himself the life of the World to Come.

A shamefaced person is not apt to learn, nor is an impatient person fitted to teach. An ignorant person19(19) For this passage, cf. Aboth II, 6 (Sonc. ed., II, 5, p. 15, nn. 3-8). cannot be pious, an uncultured person20(20) One devoid of knowledge and ethical principles. sin-fearing,21(21) He may avoid sin from fear of the consequences but not from ethical motives. or anyone who engages much22(22) And leaves little or no time for study. in business become a scholar. Put your mind, therefore, to the study of the Torah rather than to business.

Fifteen characteristics are mentioned in connection with a scholar, viz.: he is decorous in his entering and leaving,23(23) ‘And leaving’ is inserted by GRA. modest in his sitting,24(24) Does not rush to occupy a front seat. subtle25(25) In devising ways of manifesting his fear; cf. Ber. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 102). in the fear [of God], shrewd in knowledge, discerning in his ways, [his mind] is absorptive and retentive, he answers fully,26(26) He takes a considerable time before answering. asks in accordance with the subject-matter27(27) Cf. above I, 1, n. 6. and answers in accordance with the accepted decisions, listens [to others]28(28) Added by GRA. and enlarges upon each subject, goes [to seek instruction] from the wise and learns in order to teach and practise.

Be not like the topmost lintel which is inaccessible to the feet or like the doorpost29(29) lit. ‘the middle [post]’. where anyone who sits by it is troubled and which ultimately collapses. Be like the doorstep30(30) lit. ‘the nethermost post’. on which most people tread but which remains when the whole building is in ruins.31(31) Referring to the quality of humility. GRA emends the text to read: ‘Be not like a lintel which can injure the face (by a person crashing into it), nor like the doorpost which can hurt the legs and ultimately collapses; but be like the doorstep on which most people tread and which remains in its place even when the whole building collapses’.
Scholars lend dignity to a company,1(1) Or, ‘behave well in a company’. but not so ignorant men.

He who occupies himself [only] with the study of Scripture is but of indifferent merit;2(2) lit. ‘it is meritorious and not meritorious’, because the Written Torah can only be understood with the aid of the Oral Torah. with Mishnah is meritorious and rewarded for it; with Talmud there can be nothing more meritorious. Yet run always to the Mishnah more than to the Shas.3(3) Because it is more easily absorbed. For this passage, cf. B.M. 33a, b (Sonc. ed., p. 206).

Do your [teaching of] Torah gratuitously and accept no remuneration for it; because the Omnipresent gave it gratuitously4(4) Cf. Ned. 36b-37a (Sonc. ed., p. 113). As Moses taught the Elders gratuitously so must they pass their teaching on to others without pay. According to the Talmud, loc. cit., this does not apply to Scripture, for the teaching of which a fee is allowed. and one may not take a fee for the [teaching of] words of Torah. If you should accept remuneration for the [teaching of] words of Torah, you will consequently destroy [the moral constitution of] the entire world. Say not, ‘I have no money’, since all money is His,5(5) He will provide you with sustenance without having to take payment for teaching. as it is stated, Mine is the silver, and Mine the gold, saith the Lord of hosts.6(6) Hag. II, 8. If you practise charity you will merit wealth; and if you merited wealth practise charity with it. While you still possess it [live in such a manner that you] gain through it this world and also inherit the World to Come; for if you do not practise charity with it, it will suddenly disappear, as it is stated, Wilt thou set thine eyes upon it? It is gone.7(7) Prov. XXIII, 5.

Say not, ‘That man is wise8(8) Endowed by nature with great intellectual gifts. but I am not wise’,9(9) i.e. I am not so endowed and therefore it is useless for me to study. because you did not attend [upon scholars] as he did.10(10) One must make every effort to gain knowledge; cf. Meg. 6b (Sonc. ed., p. 30). Say not, ‘That man is rich but I am not rich’,11(11) Although I am more God-fearing than he. because not everyone has the privilege to enjoy two tables.12(12) i.e. enjoy prosperity in this world and the bliss of the hereafter. Say not, ‘That man is handsome but I am ugly’, because at the hour of death man becomes carrion; furthermore [animal] carrion may be sold to a Gentile or may be given as a gift, but no one cares for human carrion.13(13) So in death the difference between the handsome and the ugly ceases to exist. Say not, ‘That man is righteous but I am not righteous, because both of you are destined to give an account before the Most High. Say not, ‘That man is strong but I am weak’,14(14) And therefore unable to control my sinful desires. because strength is only with [them who fulfil] the Torah, as it is stated, Bless the Lord, ye angels of His, ye mighty in strength, that fulfil His word, hearkening unto the voice of His word.15(15) Ps. CIII, 20. So occupy yourself with the study of the Torah and you will increase moral strength.

Take these words to heart: Know whence you came, and whither you go, and before Whom you are destined to give an account and reckoning.16(16) Cf. Aboth III, 1 (Sonc. ed., p. 26). Eye not [enviously] another’s wealth because it undermines the gates of heaven.17(17) To the envious the luminaries of heaven shine but dimly.

Suffer not your ears to listen to idle chatter, because they are burnt first of [all] the organs.18(18) lit. ‘of the limbs’. From hearing unworthy or idle talk he may proceed to speak unworthy or idle words and then do unworthy or idle acts. The ear is, accordingly, the first organ to ‘catch fire’; cf. Keth. 5b (Sonc. ed., p. 18). Eye not [enviously] another’s wealth, because it may cast you into thick darkness and gloom. Let not your mouth repeat calumny, because it is the first to be summoned for judgment. Let there not be found with you calumny, any evil thing or anything stolen, because all your limbs will testify against you. Let not your feet hurry you to commit a sin lest the Angel of Death come to meet you.19(19) Lest you die before you make atonement. Be not afraid of an earthly court because the witnesses against you are lovers of money,20(20) i.e. subject to bribery. [H. Loewe, Rabbinic Anthology, p. 587, in agreement with a variant cited in H, omits the negative and renders: ‘Fear the earthly tribunal, even though witnesses against you can be bribed; fear yet more the heavenly tribunal’.] but fear the heavenly Court because there are witnesses above who testify against you, and moreover [your sins] proclaim war on you incessantly.
If you fulfilled My words joyfully, My heavenly household will go out to greet you and I will greet you with the words, ‘Enter in peace’.

Because your eyes have not looked [enviously] on another’s wealth, they will shine amidst thick darkness and gloom, as it is stated, Then shall thy light rise in darkness, and thy gloom be as the noon-day.21(21) Isa. LVIII, 10. Because your ears have not listened to idle chatter they will hear [words of] peace for you in [this] world and cause you to hear them in the World to Come, as it is stated, And thine ears shall hear a word behind thee, saying: ‘This is the way, walk ye in it; when ye turn to the right hand, and when ye turn to the left.’22(22) ibid. XXX, 21. Because your mouth did not recount calumny, all your adversaries will be slain by it.23(23) So GRA. Because your mouth occupied itself with [the teaching of] the Torah, all who are worthy of a blessing will bless themselves through it.24(24) They will wish for no greater blessing than will come to you for what you have earned by your mouth. Because you withheld your hands from plunder, what can evil persons do to you? Because you did not close your hands from almsgiving, what can violent persons25(25) lit. ‘owners of an arm’, the emendation of GRA. V has ‘owners of silver and gold’. do to you? Because your feet did not hurry you to commit a sin, what can the Angel of Death do to you?
I admonish you with these words of Mine. You can do as you please26(26) Since man is endowed with free will. but do not say, ‘I was not warned’.

A scholar should not eat standing, lick his fingers or belch in the presence of his fellow. He talks little, jokes little, sleeps in moderation, is frugal in pleasures and minimizes ‘[Yes], yes’ or ‘No, no’.1(1) Cf. Shebu. 36a (Sonc. ed., p. 211) where the repetition of ‘yes’ and ‘no’ is regarded as an oath. It may perhaps also mean to be sparing in making promises.

A man should always make a point of knowing with whom he is sitting or standing, with whom he is sitting at table, with whom he is conversing and who is his co-signatory to a deed.2(2) Cf. Sanh. 23a (Sonc. ed., p. 131).

By four things are scholars3(3) In ‘Erub. 65b (Sonc. ed., p. 455) the wording is: ‘By three things may a person’s’, etc., not only a scholar. recognizable: by their cup,4(4) By the amount of liquor they consume. their purse,5(5) By what they spend their money on. their temper6(6) In the Heb. there is an effective alliteration: kis (purse), kos (cup) and ka‘as (temper). The last indicates self-control. and by their attire.7(7) A scholar was expected to maintain cleanliness in his attire. Cf. Shab. 114a (Sonc. ed., p. 557). Some say: Also by their speech.8(8) ‘Erub. adds ‘also by their laughter’ and omits ‘by their attire’.

The adornment of [knowledge of] Torah is wisdom, the adornment of wisdom is humility, the adornment of humility is fear [of God], the adornment of the fear [of God] is the performance of meritorious deeds, the adornment of the performance of meritorious deeds is modesty.9(9) i.e. the unostentatious manner in which they are done.

A man should not be awake when among those who are asleep or asleep when among those who are awake. He should not weep when among those who are joyous or be joyous when among those who weep. He should not be sitting when among those who are standing or standing when among those who are sitting. He should not study Scripture when among those who study Mishnah or study Mishnah when among those who study Scripture. This is the general rule: A man should not act differently from the practice of his fellow-men.

Four things are unbecoming to scholars. One should not start out on a journey by night,1(1) Either because of danger or not to arouse suspicion of immoral intention. go out scented,2(2) According to Ber. 43b (Sonc. ed., p. 266) this applies to scenting one’s clothes and in a place where people are suspected of sodomy. be the last to enter the Synagogue,3(3) Ber. loc. cit., reads ‘Beth Hammidrash’. or frequent the society of ignorant persons.

On entering the elder precedes, on leaving the younger precedes;4(4) Or, ‘the more important … the less important’. Cf. Ber. 61a (Sonc. ed., p. 381): ‘In conferring honour we commence with the greatest’. when ascending a staircase the elder precedes, when descending a staircase the younger precedes; [when entering] a Council Chamber the elder precedes; [when entering] a prison the younger precedes; to pronounce a blessing5(5) At the beginning of a meal or to recite Grace after it. the elder takes precedence. The passer-by greets one who is sitting.

No person should sit down at table to eat before his elders [have taken their seat]. When cutting off a piece of bread [for Grace before meals] one should do so from the part that is baked into a crust.6(6) Cf. above, p. 553. When one is about to eat a leek or onion, he should begin to eat from the leaves.7(7) And not from the top; cf. above, p. 553. One should not take hold of a loaf, bite a piece off and place it back upon the table. When about to drink water in public, one should turn his face away and drink.8(8) Because it is customary for a scholar to exercise privacy both in eating and drinking.
A man should not be a caviller, trickster or tippler. He should overlook an insult and not glorify himself by his fellow’s humiliation.9(9) Cf. Meg. 28a (Sonc. ed., p. 168).

The first stage in committing a sin is impure thought, the second is scoffing, the third haughtiness, the fourth cruelty, the fifth idleness, the sixth causeless hatred and the seventh an evil eye.10(10) An envious nature. That is what Solomon said, When he speaketh fair, believe him not; for there are seven abominations in his heart.11(11) Prov. XXVI, 25.

There are seven characteristics in an uncultured man1(1) Heb. golem. Cf. Aboth V, 10 (Sonc. ed., V, 7, pp. 64f.). and seven in a wise man. A wise man does not speak before one who is greater than he in wisdom and in number,2(2) Of years. does not enter into the midst of the words of his fellow,3(3) i.e. does not interrupt. is not hasty to answer; he asks in accordance with the subject-matter and answers in accordance with the accepted decision, speaks on the first [point] first and on the last [point] last, concerning what he has not heard he says, ‘I have not heard it’,4(4) Cf. above, p. 571, n. 4. and acknowledges the truth.5(5) He does not consider it inconsistent with his dignity to admit when he is in the wrong. The reverse of these are in an uncultured man.

A scholar must be modest in eating, drinking, washing, anointing,6(6) i.e. rubbing with oil after a bath. putting his shoes on, walking, his attire, [the modulation of] his voice, expectorating7(7) i.e. clearing his throat. and good works.8(8) He should perform them unostentatiously. As a bride keeps herself secluded all the time she is in her father’s house and only makes herself known when she goes out9(9) Leaves her father’s house for the wedding ceremony. [as if] to say, ‘Anyone who can testify anything against me,10(10) Against her virtue. let him come and testify’, so must a scholar be modest in his [good] deeds but renowned for his conduct. He must seek truth and not falsehood, honesty and not robbery, meekness and not haughtiness, peace and not conflict, the counsel of the Elders and not the counsel of the young.11(11) Cf. Meg. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 192): ‘If old men say to you “Throw down” and young men say to you “Build up”, do the former’. He should rather walk behind a lion than behind a woman.12(12) To avoid unchaste thoughts.

He honours the wise13(13) Added by GRA. [and does not show disrespect towards them.] What is meant by ‘honours the wise’? He gives him food and drink, dresses him and puts his shoes on for him, leads him in and out. This applies to both a teacher14(14) A variant is ‘a father’ in agreement with Ḳid. 31b (Sonc. ed., p. 154). and a Sage.15(15) Although he is not his teacher. What is meant by ‘showing disrespect’? He must not sit in his [accustomed] place, speak16(16) In Ḳid. ‘stand’; cf. also Midrash Rabbah, Num., XV, 17 (Sonc. ed., p. 660). in his stead or contradict his words.

R. Ḥiyya taught: Silence is good for the wise and how much more so for fools; and so did Solomon say, Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise.17(17) Prov. XVII, 28. It is not necessary to say, ‘When a wise man holdeth his peace’.18(18) Because a wise man knows when to be silent.

Be pliable like the reed upon which the wind can blow from every direction it chooses;1(1) Cf. DER IV, p. 545. for the Torah can only endure with him who is humble in spirit. Why is the Torah likened to water?2(2) Cf. Isa. LV, 1, Ho, everyone that thirsteth, come ye for water. It is to teach you that as water does not flow [from a lower] to a higher level but [from a higher level] to a lower, so the Torah endures only with him who is humble in spirit.3(3) It flows away from him who is haughty; cf. Ta‘an. 7a (Sonc. ed., p. 27).

Keep aloof from anything hideous and from whatever resembles it,4(4) Cf. Ḥul. 44b (Sonc. ed., p. 239) and ARN II, 2, p. 18. and draw near to what [59a] is becoming and all that resembles it. Beware of one who counsels you in his own interest.5(5) lit. ‘in his own way’; cf. Sanh. 76b (Sonc. ed., p. 517).

Who waives his right to retribution6(6) lit. ‘passes by his measures’, i.e. forgoes his right to exact punishment. is forgiven all his sins, as it is stated, Who is a God like unto Thee, that pardoneth the iniquity, and passeth by the transgression,7(7) Micah VII, 18. [which means,] who is forgiven iniquity? He who passed by transgression [against himself].8(8) Cf. R.H. 17a (Sonc. ed., p. 67).

Whoever abases [mithnabbel] himself in connection with words of Torah9(9) i.e. is not ashamed to ask questions which may at first sound foolish; cf. Ber. 63b (Sonc. ed., p. 402). will in the end be exalted on its account, as it is stated If thou hast done foolishly [nabalta] in lifting up thyself,10(10) Prov. XXX, 32. [which means,] if you have abased yourself for words of the Torah, in the end you will be exalted.
He who seeks [knowledge of] the Torah, added wisdom will be given to him,11(11) Following the emended text of GRA. as it is stated, Give to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser.12(12) ibid. IX, 9.
So long as a person is a sinner he has fear of his fellow-creatures; but so long as he is not a sinner his fellow-creatures have fear of him.13(13) They are afraid of his knowing about their guilt.

Whoever makes light of a single point of the Torah is liable to kareth, as it is stated, Because he hath despised the word of the Lord … that soul shall utterly be cut off.14(14) Num. XV, 31. And he who makes light of the [precept of] washing the hands will be uprooted from the world.15(15) Added by GRA. Cf. Soṭah 4b (Sonc. ed., p. 16).

Whoever is not shamefaced will readily sin, as it is stated, The show of their countenance doth witness against them;16(16) Isa. III, 9. but he who experiences shame17(17) i.e. who is not callous, but is self-conscious when he is doing wrong. will not readily sin, as it is stated, [And Moses said unto the people: ‘Fear not; for God is come to prove you] and that His fear may be before you, that ye sin not.18(18) Ex. XX, 17; cf. Ned. 20a (Sonc. ed., p. 57).

It is unbecoming for a host to eat in the presence of his guest [without inviting him to join him]; it is more unbecoming for one guest to bring in another guest;19(19) Cf. B.B. 98b (Sonc. ed., p. 410), a saying attributed to Ben Sira. it is still more unbecoming when one eats in the presence of a scholar. More unbecoming than these three is for a guest to cause trouble to another guest.20(20) GRA reads ‘his host’. R. Meir said: [Most unbecoming of all is] he who takes [food] set before him and gives it to the host’s child; for it once happened that [through such an action] a host killed his child.21(21) Cf. DER IX, 3, p. 559.

He who humbles himself will understand his instruction and whoever transgresses the words of the Sages deserves kareth.22(22) GRA reads: ‘He who attends upon scholars comprehends his instruction, and whoever does not comprehend his instruction deserves death’. Whoever [continually] declares [others] unfit is [himself] unfit.23(23) Cf. DER I, 12, p. 535. R. ‘Aḳiba said: The beginning of my attendance upon the Sages24(24) Cf. Semaḥoth IV, 16, above p. 342. was this. I was once on a journey when I came across a meth miẓwah which I carried about four mil until I brought it to a cemetery and buried it there. When I appeared before R. Eliezer and R. Joshua and told them what had happened, they said to me, ‘Every step you took is reckoned against you as if you had shed blood’.25(25) He should have buried the corpse where he found it. I said to them, ‘If, in a case where I intended to perform a meritorious act I have made myself liable like a wicked person, how much more [will I deserve punishment] when I have no [meritorious] intention! From that moment I did not let an opportunity pass to minister to the Sages’.26(26) He learned by associating with scholars. He used to say: One who does not minister to the Sages deserves death.

He who enters a bath-house should first remove his cloak, then the shoes, then the trousers and then the shirt.27(27) This rendering is in accordance with GRA and H. V reads: ‘If [the pupil] brought [the Sages] into a bath-house, he should first remove the cloak’, etc., referring to the duty to minister to the learned.

He who is about to enter a bath-house should respect28(28) By giving way. the one who is about to leave,29(29) By not hurrying him unduly and the one who is about to leave a privy must respect the one who is about to enter.30(30) He must hurry so as not to keep the other waiting; cf. DER X, 2, p. 561.
R. Eliezer Ha-Ḳappar said: Keep aloof from making complaints, because if you complain against others you will be led to further sin.2(2) To hatred, quarrel and slander; cf. above I, 15, p. 569.

Love him who reproves you so that you may increase knowledge; and hate him who flatters3(3) lit. ‘honours, praises’. Praise may discourage one from further study. you so that your knowledge may not decrease.

Love the Synagogue that you may receive your reward daily.4(4) Cf. Ber. 8a (Sonc. ed., p. 39). Love the House of Study that your children may come to study the Torah.5(5) Copying the example of their parents. Love the poor that your children may not come to that condition. Love meekness that you may complete [the number of] your years.6(6) So GRA. V reads ‘fill your hands’; H ‘your days’, reading yameka for yadeka. Love the pious7(7) By emulating them. that you may be saved from the Angel of Darkness.8(8) According to NY he is so called because the Angel of Death makes the face of man black. H reads ‘Angel of Death’.

Be heedful in the reading of the Shema‘ and the ‘Amidah9(9) To recite them at the proper time and with devotion; cf. Aboth II, 18 (Sonc. ed., II, 13, p. 22). that you may be saved from the judgment of Gehinnom. Let your house be open wide10(10) ibid. I, 5 (Sonc. ed., p. 4). that you may have no lack of food. Be heedful not to shut the doors of your house when you sit down to eat and drink, because the doors of your house may bring you to poverty.10a(10a) They will shut out prosperity from you.

Be heedful to honour11(11) GRA omits ‘to honour’ and reads ‘with respect to your wife’, alluding to conjugal rights. Cf. B.M. 59a (Sonc. ed., p. 352). your wife12(12) A wife is sensitive and quick to feel and resent a hurt. that she become not barren. Be happy when sufferings come upon you, because they deliver you from the punishment of Gehinnom.13(13) So GRA. If sufferings are interpreted as punishment for wrongdoing they induce a feeling of remorse and lead to repentance. Rejoice at your table when the hungry benefit from it so that your life may be prolonged in this world and in the World to Come.

Be happy when you donate gifts [of charity] quietly14(14) lit. ‘from your house’. so that the anger [of the Angel of Death]15(15) GRA omits ‘the Angel of Death’ and it may refer to God’s anger. may be diverted from you, as it is stated, A gift in secret pacifieth anger, and a present in the bosom strong wrath.16(16) Prov. XXI, 14.

If you have restrained yourself from doing a good deed, the Angel of Death will come to meet you.17(17) And you will be prevented from making good the omission. If you have exerted yourself18(18) lit. ‘scattered your foot generously’. in connection with the poor or the fulfilment of a precept, there will be fulfilled in you Blessed shalt thou be when thou comest in, and blessed shalt thou be when thou goest out.19(19) Deut. XXVIII, 6. If you guarded your mouth from slander, all the days of your life will be spent in peace; but if you were presumptuous towards a person greater than yourself, you will ultimately be stricken with skin disease.20(20) Cf. ‘Arak. 16a (Sonc. ed., p. 91): ‘Because of seven things the plague of leprosy is incurred: These are: slander’, etc. Cf. the incident of Miriam (Num. XII, 1ff.).

If you withheld yourself from performing a meritorious act and occupied yourself with a sinful act, your wife will ultimately die of a stroke, as it is stated, Son of man, behold, I take away from thee the desire of thine eyes with a stroke.21(21) Ezek. XXIV, 16.

If you bestirred yourself to honour a Sage, you will have perfect sons and daughters; and if you bestirred yourself to honour a poor man, you will have children in Israel who are learned in Torah and perform the commandments. If you were present at the death of a Sage, do not leave him until you have accompanied him to the grave,22(22) Cf. Shab. 105b (Sonc. ed., p. 509) for rites to be observed on the death of a Sage. so that when you die you may enter and rest in the grave in peace.23(23) From ‘so that’ is added by GRA instead of V which inserts here the last clause of §11.

If you notice that your fellow’s face is worried because he has become poor, do not send him away empty-handed, in order that you may be delivered from all evil;24(24) ‘In order … evil’ is added by GRA. as it is stated, Whoso keepeth the commandment shall know no evil thing.25(25) Eccl. VIII, 5. If you have given him a loan in the time of his emergency, there will be fulfilled in you Then shalt thou call, and the Lord will answer.26(26) Isa. LVIII, 9.

If you have humbled yourself, the Holy One, blessed be He, will lift you up; if you have exalted yourself before your fellow, the Holy One, blessed be He, will set you low. Should people strive27(27) So GRA; V ‘honour’. with you, whether it be in the House of Study or at a social gathering,28(28) lit. ‘in a sitting [for study] or in a reclining [at a meal]’. make peace with them, so that when you leave them29(29) lit. ‘on your return [home]’. they may speak well of you, as was spoken of Phinehas the son of Eleazar.30(30) Cf. Num. XXV, 10-13. The translation follows GRA instead of V’s senseless ‘so that he may come and rest upon your bed’.

And so used R. Eleazar Ha-Ḳappar to say: Love peace and hate dissension. Great is peace, for even if [Israel] were to practise idolatry but maintained peace among themselves, the Divine Presence, as it were, would be unable to do them harm, as it is stated, Ephraim is joined to idols; let him alone.31(31) Hos. IV, 17. Cf. Midrash Rabbah, Num., XI, 7 (Sonc. ed., p. 441) where the reading is: ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, as it were, says: Satan shall not touch them’. In Midrash Rabbah, Gen., XXXVIII, 6 (Sonc. ed., p. 306) the version is: ‘The Holy One, blessed be He, says: I have no dominion over them’. But if there is dissension between them, what is stated of them? Their heart is divided; now shall they bear their guilt.32(32) Hos. X, 2. A house in which is dissension will ultimately be destroyed. A Synagogue [in which is dissension] will ultimately be turned into a place of idolatry.33(33) So GRA; cf. Yeb. 96b (Sonc. ed., p. 660). V reads: ‘The Sages said: When there is dissension in a Synagogue it will be cut in pieces’. If two scholars reside in the same city who have set up separate Courts of Law and dissension occurs between them, they will ultimately die [prematurely].34(34) Cf. Soṭah 49a (Sonc. ed., p. 263). Abba Saul said: Dissension between separate Courts of Law is the ruination of the world.

Abba Isi b. Joḥanan said in the name of Samuel the Small: This world is likened to a person’s eyeball: the white of the eye [corresponds to] the ocean which surrounds the whole world; the iris to the [inhabited] world; the pupil of the eye to Jerusalem; the face in the pupil to the Temple. May it be rebuilt speedily in our days and in the days of all Israel, Amen.

R. Simeon b. Joḥai said: As for the seven-year cycle in which the son of David will come, in the first year will be fulfilled And I caused it to rain upon one city, and caused it not to rain upon another city;1(1) Amos IV, 7. There will be famine in one place and plenty in another. in the second, the arrows of hunger will be sent forth;2(2) i.e. not actual famine, but the first signs of it, nobody being completely satisfied. in the third there will be a severe famine in the course of which men, women and children will die, pious men and miracle workers become scarce, and the Torah will be forgotten by its students;3(3) Through lack of food. in the fourth, there will be partial plenty;4(4) lit. ‘plenty and no plenty’. in the fifth, great plenty when men will eat, drink and rejoice and the Torah will be restored to its disciples;5(5) ‘And the Torah’, etc., is added by GRA. in the sixth [there will be heard heavenly] sounds;6(6) Either heavenly voices announcing the advent of the Messiah or the blasts of the great shofar; cf. Isa. XXVII, 13. in the seventh, wars [will be waged]; and at the expiration of the septennate the son of David will come.7(7) Cf. Sanh. 97a (Sonc. ed., pp. 654f.) for this and the following passages; also Midrash to Song of Songs II, 13 (Sonc. ed., p. 126). Rabban Gamaliel said: In the generation when the son of David comes, the house of assembly8(8) Where scholars gather. will be a brothel, Galilee will be in ruins, and the inhabitants of Gablan9(9) The Jews living along the borders of the Land of Israel. Gablan is to be read for Galil, ‘Galilee’, as in Sanh., loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 655, n. 4). will wander about [begging] from city to city without experiencing pity; the wisdom of scribes will be in disfavour and God-fearing men despised, the leaders of the people10(10) lit. ‘the face of the generation’. will be dog-faced;11(11) Shameless. truth will be lacking, and he that departs from evil will be regarded as demented. R. Nehorai said: In the generation when the son of David comes, young men will insult the old, the aged will stand up before youth,12(12) To do them honour. a daughter will rise up against her mother and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law,13(13) Cf. Micah VII, 6. and a son will not be abashed in his father’s14(14) So GRA and H. V has ‘mother’s’. presence. R. Nehemiah said: In the generation when the son of David comes, impudence will increase, esteem will be perverted,15(15) No one will esteem another. Or, even the nobility and most honoured will degenerate. the vine will yield its fruit yet wine will be dear,16(16) Drunkenness will increase so that in spite of the abundant yield there will be a scarcity. and the government will be converted to heresy17(17) Heb. minuth. By ‘the kingdom’ the Roman Empire is meant, and the statement is a remarkable forecast by R. Nehemiah (100 C.E.) of the conversion of Rome to Christianity under Constantine the Great in 313 C.E. Cf. however, Herford, Christianity in Talmud and Midrash, pp. 207ff., Sanh., loc. cit. (Sonc. ed., p. 656, n. 4). with none to reprove. 2. R. Jose said: Two are better than three,18(18) So GRA. The two legs in youth are better than the three, i.e. the addition of a stick in old age for walking. and alas for the one thing19(19) Youth. which goes and does not return. He used to say: We do not appoint as leader of the community one who is a blood-letter,20(20) lit. ‘a scraper’, one who makes incisions in the skin to draw off blood. a tanner or a builder;21(21) Because their occupation is mean; cf. Ḳid. 82a (Sonc. ed., p. 424). nor do we appoint any of them as an administrator.22(22) ibid. He used to say: They who dwell in villages and they who travel in the wilderness lead a miserable life,23(23) lit. ‘their life is no life’. their money is not secure,24(24) lit. ‘not their money’; they can easily be robbed. and their children are not their own.25(25) Their wives are not safe from attack; cf. ‘Erub. 55b (Sonc. ed., p. 391).

Four peruṭoth26(26) i.e. the monies earned from the four occupations enumerated. are without a sign of blessing.27(27) It is therefore not advisable to engage in them. They are: the wages of scribes,28(28) Cf. Pes. 50b (Sonc. ed., p. 246) where the reference is to writers of Torah-scrolls, tefillin and mezuzoth; if they become wealthy they would no longer write them. the wages of interpreters,29(29) Officials who delivered the Sabbath lectures of the Rabbi to the congregation. The Rabbi whispered his statement to the interpreter, who elaborated it to the people. It includes the translators of the weekly lections of the Torah on the Sabbath in the Synagogue. The reason given in Pes. is that it appears like wages for Sabbath work. money that came from overseas,30(30) Danger attended the transport of freights by sea and one might suffer loss. and he who marries for the sake of a dowry.31(31) Pes. has instead ‘the profit of orphans’, i.e. derived by trading with trust money. These will not be able to bequeath anything to their children or grandchildren.

There are some who marry for sexual indulgence, and there are some who marry for money. There are some who marry for social advancement32(32) lit. ‘greatness’. and there are some who marry with sincere intention.33(33) lit. ‘for the sake of heaven’, to fulfil the command to procreate. Of him who marries for sexual indulgence Scripture declares, They have dealt treacherously against the Lord, for they have begotten strange children.34(34) Hos. V, 7. In Ḳid. 70a (Sonc.ed., p.354) the verse is applied to one who marries for money and it states that ‘he will have unworthy children’, the word strange meaning ‘strange from the ways of decency’. Of him who marries for money Scripture declares, Now shall the new moon devour them with their portions,35(35) ibid. [implying] a month comes and a month goes and their money is gone. He who marries for social advancement will ultimately be deposed from his high position; but he who marries with sincere intention will ultimately have children who will be saviours of Israel.

The adornment of God is mankind; the adornment of mankind is the Torah;36(36) So GRA. V has ‘their garments’; cf. Shab. 113b (Sonc. ed., p. 556). the adornment of the Torah is wisdom; the adornment of old age is grey hair; the adornment of youth is the fear of sin; the adornment of an ‘am ha-’areẓ is a curse.37(37) The opposite of ‘blessing’ which he deserves for the neglect of the Torah. The meaning is obscure. Two possibilities suggest themselves. 1) That he deserves nothing more than a curse (and this reflects the reciprocal hostility we find elsewhere between the ע״ה and the scholar. 2) That a curse comes most readily to the lips of an ע״ה.

He who learnt Scripture but not Mishnah is a boor; he who learnt Mishnah and not Scripture is an ‘am ha-’areẓ;38(38) The reading in Ber. 47b (Sonc. ed., p. 287) and Soṭah 22a (Sonc. ed., p. 110) is: ‘Even if he learnt Scripture and Mishnah but did not attend upon Rabbinical scholars, he is an ‘am ha-’areẓ’. he who learnt Scripture and Mishnah but has not expounded them is a scholar; he who learnt Scripture and Mishnah and expounded them is an intelligent man; and as for him who learnt neither Scripture nor Mishnah, better for him if he had not been born.
